*145Justice LaVECCHIA
delivered the opinion of the Court.

caseNameFull: Edward Furstein v. Rita B. Hill

opinions.snippet:
Peters, C. J.
The dispositive issue in this consolidated appeal is whether a police officer occupies the status of an invitee or of a licensee when, in the course of performing his official duties, he is injured by a defective condition on the property of a landowner. Spivey was convicted in the Muscogee Superior Court of murder, kidnapping, armed robbery, and aggravated assault. opinions.snippet: FOSHEIM, Chief Justice (on reassignment). This case reappears following our remand for the entry of findings of fact and conclusions of law regarding defendant’s motion to suppress evidence. The factual background was set forth in our opinion issued in the first appeal. See State v. Janis, 321 N.W.2d 527 (S.D.1982). We supplement the facts as necessary to address the issues now presented.

caseNameFull: UNITED STATES of America, Appellee, v. Edward Lunn TULL, Appellant
court: Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit

opinions.snippet:
HARRISON L. WINTER, Chief Judge:
Defendant Tull, a real estate developer, placed fill on “wetlands” without a permit at several locations on the island of Chincoteague, Virginia. The government sued, alleging that this filling violated both the Clean Water Act,1 33 U.S.C. § 1251 et seq., and the Rivers and Harbors Appropriation Act, 33 U.S.C. § 401 et seq.
